container-title: Good historical reviews of the major systems are found in Reading the Past
title: and intelligent essays by French scholars. Badly outdated, but still rich in information, is David Diringer’s The Alphabet: A Key to the History of Mankind, a general history of writing, in spite of the title; originally published in 1947, it was reissued in 1996 (New Delhi). A strong linguistic approach, which can be misleading, underlies books by Florian Coulmas, The Writing Systems of the World
Geoffrey Sampson, Writing Systems: A Linguistic Introduction
and Henry Rogers Writing Systems: A Linguistic Approach
The Rogers book, designed as a textbook, has an excellent bibliography
H. Jensen’s Sign, Symbol, Script
a version of Die Schrift in Vergangenheit und Gegenwart

container-title: J. Gelb’s A Study of Writing
title: An attractive and readable essay, with much fine sense, is R. Harris Origin of Writing
A fine popular study is The Story of Writing: Alphabets, Hieroglyphs, and Pictograms

Most of these books use inconsistent or contradictory terminology, call almost anything a pictogram, find ideograms everywhere, and confuse alphabets with syllabaries. Nonetheless they contain useful charts and other information. By far the best general book, and still basic after half a century, is I

note: Also excellent is Michael Roaf’s Cultural Atlas of Mesopotamia and the Ancient
title: For an understanding of the complex history of the ancient Near East, background to developments in the history of writing, exemplary are Amelie Kuhrt’s two-volume The Ancient Near East, c.3000–330 bc
A History of the Ancient Near East ca. 3000–323 bc

container-title: For decipherments, Maurice Pope’s The Story of Decipherment: From Egyptian Hieroglyphs to Maya Script
title: For the general conditions of prehistory, Colin Renfrew’s Prehistory: The making of Mankind (London, 2007) is inspiring

note: Origins of writing Denise Schmandt-Besserat has nicely summarized her argument in How Writing
title: Andrew Robinson’s Lost Languages: The World’s Undeciphered Scripts (New York, 2002) has up-to-date information about Linear A, Etruscan, and other undeciphered scripts

container-title: J
note: Nissen, P. Damerow, and R. Englund, Archaic Bookkeeping
title: an abridgment of the two-volume Before Writing
Early results from the Berlin team working on protocuneiform are published in H
one of the best books on the origins of lexigraphic writing. R. Englund has a thorough treatment of the origin and early phases of cuneiform in “Texts from the Late Uruk Period
Mesopotamien: Späturuk-Zeit and Frühdynastische Zeit, Orbis Biblicus und Orientalis 160/1
Also excellent on the origins of cuneiform (though in French) is Jean-Jacques Glassner’s Ecrire à Sumer: Invention de cunéiform
Houston’s The First Writing: Script Invention as History and Process

is up to date with fine or superb essays on the origins of writing by philologists deep in their disciplines, with discussion of the theory of how speech relates to written representation (though in its theoretical descriptions it is inconsistent and sometimes jargonistic). A superior web source for the study of the protocuneiform tablets is

container-title: in the collection Reading the Past: Ancient Writing from Cuneiform to the Alphabet
note: Austin, 2007), Denise Schmandt-Besserat investigates the effect of literacy on visual art, explaining how conventions of writing inspired complex narrative in art (as on the Uruk Vase and the Narmer Palette); conversely, art influenced what writing wished to accomplish. Egyptian hieroglyphs For cultural background to Egypt, Barry Kemp’s Ancient Egypt: Anatomy of a
title: 04/02/2009 02:32PM Page 265 Bibliography 265 Cuneiform All general studies of writing have chapters on cuneiform including C
Walker’s excellent “Cuneiform
Jean Bottéro’s Mesopotamia: Writing
is a superior study of the role of writing in Mesopotamia by a leading Assyriologist
In a recent book, When Writing Met Art

container-title: James P. Allen’s Middle Egyptian : An Introduction to the Language and Culture of Hieroglyphs
originally Copenhagen
note: gives a modern in-depth view, with excellent essays on individual topics. Antonio Loprieno’s Ancient Egyptian: A Linguistic Introduction (Cambridge, UK, 1995) will interest those with a linguistic bent. Though outdated in various aspects, Sir Alan Gardiner’s triumphant Egyptian grammar
title: Civilisation is superlative
A recent translation of Horapollo’s influential treatise is by G. Boas, The Hieroglyphics of Horapollo, with a foreword by Anthony T
The strange Hypnerotomachia Poliphili: The Strife of Love in a Dream has now been published for the first time in English
A compelling review of the Neoplatonic impediments to the decipherment is given in E. Iversen The Myth of Egypt and Its Hieroglyphs in European Tradition
Davies provides a good sketch of the Egyptian system in Egyptian Hieroglyphs
published separately and as one of the chapters
Reading the Past. Egyptian writing and its different forms and uses is also well described in R. B. Parkinson’s Cracking Codes: The Rosetta Stone and its Decipherment

John Baines’s “The Earliest Egyptian Writing” (in The First Writing) is the best summary of the topic. Egyptian may be more fun to read than cuneiform and M. Collier and Bill Manley have written the exemplary (and best selling) How to Read Egyptian Hieroglyphs: A Step-By-Step Guide to Teach Yourself (Berkeley, 1998) that teaches in a practical way how a logosyllabic writing works

container-title: R. Driver, in Semitic Writing from Pictograph to Alphabet
The Origins of Writing
The standard review of early remains of West Semitic is J. Naveh’s Early History of the Alphabet (Leiden
note: that is, of West Semitic writing, an example of a leading epigrapher careless with history. Chinese writing There is a good background to the subject in S. Robert Ramsey, The Languages
title: West Semitic writing is a central topic in all handbooks, but always badly skewed by the word “alphabet” and the theory of the origin of West Semitic signs from “pictograms” via the acrophonic principle. Hence the rich and valuable, but oldfashioned, contributions of G
Hopkins) need to be read with caution. The short summary in John Healey’s The Early Alphabet
also in Hooker’s Reading the Past) is short and sweet, as is F. M. Cross’s essay “The Invention and Development of the Alphabet
The summaries of the varieties of West Semitic in Daniels and Bright (Oxford, 1996) are useful

title: More than any single book, Linda Schele and Mary Ellen Miller’s The Blood of Kings: Dynasty and Ritual in Maya Art, an exhibition catalogue from Fort Worth
changed popular perceptions of the Maya from that of gentle forest dwellers to blood-addicted warlords. Linda Schele was one of the pioneers of the Maya decipherment and
